qas.question: Who developed a device that improved on the shortcomings of Scheiner's invention?

answers.text: Austrian scientist Josef Maria Eder (1855–1944) and Flemish-born botanist Walter Hecht (de)

qas.question: What did the Eder-Hecht device measure?
What method did manufacturers use much of the time to compare film speeds?
What type of measurement methods began to proliferate?

plausible_answers.text: Josef Maria Eder (1855–1944) and Flemish-born botanist Walter Hecht (de)

qas.question: Who caused the shortcomings in the Scheiner invention?
What device allowed manufacturers to reliably determine speed?
What was revised to a measure a tighter range?
What made comparability a more common option?
What scientist suggested comparing the systems?

context: <b7_0>The system<b7_0/> was later extended to cover larger ranges and some of its practical shortcomings were addressed by the <a0_0>Austrian scientist <b5_0><b9_0>Josef Maria Eder<b9_0/> (1855–1944) and Flemish-born botanist Walter Hecht (de)<b5_0/><a0_0/> (1896–1960), (who, in 1919/1920, jointly developed their <b6_0>Eder–Hecht neutral wedge sensitometer<b6_0/> measuring <a1_0>emulsion speeds<a1_0/> in Eder–Hecht grades). Still, it remained difficult for manufactures to reliably determine film speeds, often only by <a2_0>comparing with competing products<a2_0/>, so that an increasing number of <a3_0><a4_0><b8_0>modified semi-Scheiner-based systems<b8_0/><a4_0/><a3_0/> started to spread, which no longer followed Scheiner's original procedures and thereby defeated the idea of comparability.
